name: Kepler-209
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-209 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-209 is a star with 0.857 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.94 times its radius. It is located 1913.49 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-209 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-209 b

Kepler-209 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.12 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 16.09 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-209.

The mass of Kepler-209 b is 6.84 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-209 b is 2.26 that of Earth. At 6.84 Earth masses, Kepler-209 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-209 c

Kepler-209 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.23 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 41.75 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-209.

The mass of Kepler-209 c is 14.59 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-209 c is 3.1 that of Earth. At more than 10 Earth masses, Kepler-209 c is an ice giant, a planet that is made up mostly of volatiles like water, amonia and methane, and enveloped by a dense hydrogen and helium atmosphere, much like Uranus and Neptune in our solar system.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-209, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
